dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Biden's veto on that Hong Kong bill is, uh, a pretty significant move.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Biden's veto on that Hong Kong bill is, uh, a pretty significant move.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: President Donald Trump signed a bill on Wednesday that supports the pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong, after days of uncertainty surrounding his willingness to confront Beijing as he attempts to hammer out a trade deal with China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? After all that lobbying from Beijing and their trade reps, it's not entirely surprising, but still—Congress had passed it overwhelmingly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? After all that lobbying from Beijing and their trade reps, it's not entirely surprising, but still-Congress had passed it overwhelmingly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The bill, the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act, was passed almost unanimously by both houses of Congress last week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and he cited the strong ties with China and President Xi specifically. Said the bill threatened that "delicate balance."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and he cited the strong ties with China and President Xi specifically. Said the bill threatened that delicate balance.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a statement announcing the signing, Trump said he signed the bill out of respect for President Xi, China and the people of Hong Kong.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is interesting because, like, Senator Lindsey Graham was just saying the U.S. now has no tools to interfere in China's Hong Kong dealings.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is interesting because, like, Senator Lindsey Graham was just saying the U.S. now has no tools to interfere in China's Hong Kong dealings.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The U.S. now has new and meaningful tools to deter further influence and interference from Beijing into Hong Kongs internal affairs, said Senator Marco Rubio, who introduced the bill.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm. And this comes right after those elections in Hong Kong with, you know, record voter suppression. Makes the veto feel even more pointed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm. And this comes right after those elections in Hong Kong with, you know, record voter suppression. Makes the veto feel even more pointed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Following last weekends historic elections in Hong Kong that included record turnout, this new law could not be more timely in showing strong U.S. support for Hong Kongers long-cherished freedoms.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. And up until today, everyone thought Biden would actually sign it into law. He'd been pretty outspoken before.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. And up until today, everyone thought Biden would actually sign it into law. He'd been pretty outspoken before.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Until today it was unclear if Trump would sign the bill into law.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then he also told CNN last week—he said, "We have to stand with Beijing, but I'm also standing with the people of Hong Kong." Kind of a mixed message.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then he also told C N N last week-he said, We have to stand with Beijing, but I'm also standing with the people of Hong Kong. Kind of a mixed message.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In an interview on Fox and Friends last week, Trump said, We have to stand with Hong Kong, but Im also standing with President Xi, when asked if he would sign the bill.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a tough line to walk. Especially with that extradition bill hanging over everything earlier—those protests really died down after that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a tough line to walk. Especially with that extradition bill hanging over everything earlier-those protests really died down after that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the bill has been withdrawn from consideration, the protests have become a larger movement against Beijings control over the city, sometimes devolving into violent clashes between protesters and police officers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, the fear was people accused of crimes in the U.S. could just flee to Hong Kong to avoid justice.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, the fear was people accused of crimes in the U.S. could just flee to Hong Kong to avoid justice.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pro-democracy protests erupted in the semiautonomous region of Hong Kong months ago over a bill that would extradite those accused of committing a crime in Hong Kong to mainland China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So this veto… it really leaves things in a complicated spot, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So this veto... it really leaves things in a complicated spot, doesn't it?

artist_script:
Biden's veto on that Hong Kong bill is, uh, a pretty significant move.
HostB: Right? After all that lobbying from Beijing and their trade reps, it’s not entirely surprising, but still—Congress had passed it overwhelmingly.
HostA: Yeah, and he cited the strong ties with China and President Xi specifically. Said the bill threatened that "delicate balance."
HostB: Which is interesting because, like, Senator Lindsey Graham was just saying the U.S. now has no tools to interfere in China’s Hong Kong dealings.
HostA: Mhm. And this comes right after those elections in Hong Kong with, you know, record voter suppression. Makes the veto feel even more pointed.
HostB: Definitely. And up until today, everyone thought Biden would actually sign it into law. He’d been pretty outspoken before.
HostA: But then he also told CNN last week—he said, "We have to stand with Beijing, but I’m also standing with the people of Hong Kong." Kind of a mixed message.
HostB: Yeah, it’s a tough line to walk. Especially with that extradition bill hanging over everything earlier—those protests really died down after that.
HostA: Right, the fear was people accused of crimes in the U.S. could just flee to Hong Kong to avoid justice.
HostB: So this veto… it really leaves things in a complicated spot, doesn’t it?
